questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious at home. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and reports recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. His wife mentions that he has been trying a new "natural" supplement along with his prescribed insulin. On arrival, his blood glucose is 45 mg/dL. Laboratory tests reveal undetectable serum C-peptide levels. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his hypoglycemia?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Exogenous insulin administration

questions.text: Where in the tubule would a patient with severe central diabetes insipidus have the lowest tubular fluid osmolality?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Stepwise Reasoning

 

  1. Central Diabetes Insipidus (DI):
    • ADH is absent.
    • Collecting ducts become impermeable to water.
    • No water reabsorption occurs in collecting ducts.
    • Urine becomes maximally dilute (hypo-osmotic).
  2. Tubular fluid osmolality along nephron in DI:
    • Proximal tubule (A): isotonic (~300 mOsm/L).
    • Descending limb: hypertonic (water leaves, solutes retained).
    • Ascending limb (B, C): impermeable to water, NaCl reabsorbed → tubular fluid becomes progressively hypotonic (~100 mOsm/L).
    • Collecting duct (D):
      • Normally, ADH makes it permeable → water reabsorbed, urine concentrated.
      • In central DI, no ADH → remains impermeable → tubular fluid becomes even more dilute (as low as 50–70 mOsm/L).
  3. Lowest osmolality site:
    → Collecting duct (D) in the absence of ADH.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man has had worsening exercise intolerance for the past year. On physical examination, he has 4/5 motor strength in the extremities, but has no muscle pain or loss of joint mobility. He has pitting edema to the knees. A deltoid muscle biopsy specimen is obtained. The figure shows the immunohistochemical staining pattern with antibody to dystrophin (A, normal; B, patient). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Becker muscular dystrophy

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1-b, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a

choices.text: Granulomatous inflammation of the terminal ileum

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of an 8-month history of fatigue, intermittent postprandial abdominal bloating and discomfort, foul-smelling, watery diarrhea, and a 7kg (15-lb) weight loss. She developed a pruritic rash on her knees 3 days ago. Physical examination shows several tense, excoriated vesicles on the knees bilaterally. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.2 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 76 um3. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to a history of recurrent infections. Over the past year, she has had multiple episodes of bacterial skin and respiratory infections requiring antibiotic treatment. Physical examination reveals silvery hair, pale skin with multiple areas of scarring from previous infections. A peripheral blood smear is obtained and shown below. Which of the following disorders is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Chédiak-Higashi syndrome

choices.text: ii, iii, iv, v are correct

questions.text:
Counter current mechanism is found in:

 

  1. Eye 
  2. Testis
  3. Gut 
  4. Kidney
  5. Lungs
questions.solution: Ans. D) ii, iii, iv, v are correct

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of weight loss, fever, and a persistent cough. Imaging of the chest reveals bilateral apical opacities with cavitation. A lung biopsy is performed, which is shown below. Which of the following cell surface markers is most specific for the cells predominantly found surrounding the necrotic tissue?
questions.solution: Ans. C) CD14

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of blood in her stool, fatigue, and weight loss over the past 2 months. However, her father died of colorectal cancer at age 45, and her younger sister has been treated for endometrial cancer. Colonoscopy reveals a right-sided mass without polyps, and biopsy shows adenocarcinoma. Which of the following gene mutations is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) MSH2

choices.text: Iodide uptake by the thyroid gland
Peripheral conversion of T4 to T3

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of weight loss, heat intolerance, palpitations, and insomnia over the past 4 months. Her vital signs are blood pressure 140/85 mm Hg, pulse 110/min, and regular. On examination, the thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and non-tender. Laboratory studies reveal decreased serum TSH and elevated free thyroxine (T4) levels. Methimazole is initiated as treatment. Which of the following processes is most likely inhibited by this treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coupling of iodotyrosine

 

Methimazole inhibits thyroid peroxidase, preventing the coupling of iodotyrosines to form T3 and T4, thereby reducing thyroid hormone synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iodide uptake by the thyroid gland: Methimazole does not inhibit iodide uptake; that is the function of the sodium-iodide symporter.

 

Option C. Peripheral conversion of T4 to T3: It does not affect peripheral conversion of T4 to T3; drugs like propranolol or amiodarone influence that.

 

Option D. Colloid production: Colloid production is not directly affected by methimazole.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for follow-up after experiencing a near-drowning incident that led to ARDS. He was mechanically ventilated for 2 weeks and subsequently discharged. The patient now reports persistent exertional dyspnea and mild fatigue. Which of the following parameters is most likely increased compared to a child with normal cardiopulmonary function?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Alveolar-arterial oxygen difference

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the clinic with headache, fatigue, fever, and a persistent dry cough. She reports that the symptoms began 2 weeks ago during a school trip. A chest X-ray reveals diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Laboratory testing shows hemolytic anemia with elevated reticulocyte count. Blood samples drawn into anticoagulated tubes are stored on ice, and visible clumping is observed when cold. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mycoplasma pneumoniae 

 

Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection can cause atypical pneumonia with diffuse interstitial infiltrates and cold agglutinin autoimmune hemolytic anemia, as indicated by clumping of red cells at cold temperatures. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Legionella pneumophila: Causes severe atypical pneumonia but not associated with cold agglutinins. 

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: Typically causes lobar pneumonia, not interstitial infiltrates. 

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae: Associated with bacterial pneumonia but not cold agglutinin hemolytic anemia.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use disorder is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious at home. He was last seen well 8 hours ago. Respiratory rate: 10/min, Oxygen saturation: 88% on room air. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals:

 

  • pH: 7.22
  • PaCO₂: 60 mm Hg
  • HCO₃⁻: 24 mEq/L

 

Which of the following is the most likely current acid-base status in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Uncompensated respiratory acidosis

questions.text: A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman presents for evaluation of her low bone density noted during a routine screening. She is started on oral risedronate to address her bone loss. What is the primary mechanism through which this medication improves bone density?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased osteoclast apoptosis

 

Risedronate is a bisphosphonate that binds to bone and induces osteoclast apoptosis, reducing bone resorption and thereby increasing bone density. Its main effect is antiresorptive, not anabolic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stimulation of osteoblast activity: Risedronate does not directly stimulate osteoblast activity.

 

Option B. Decreased stimulation of RANK ligand (RANKL): It does not affect RANKL signaling directly; it targets osteoclasts.

 

Option C. Increased intestinal calcium absorption: It does not increase intestinal calcium absorption; that is the action of vitamin D.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to persistent pain and swelling in her hands for the past 10 years. She reports morning stiffness lasting 2 hours, which improves with activity. On examination, there is gross deformity of multiple joints in both hands. Wrist Xray is given below.  The condition causing these findings would most likely affect which of the following regions of the spine?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Cervical spine

choices.text: High calcium, Low phosphorus, High ALP
Normal calcium, Normal phosphorus, Normal ALP
High calcium, high phosphorus, High ALP
Normal calcium, Normal phosphorus, High ALP

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the clinic due to progressively worsening pain in his lower limbs for the past 6 months. He reports the pain is deep and aching and worsens with activity. There is no history of trauma or fever. On examination, the legs are bowed with palpable warmth over the shins, and imaging shows trabecular thickening and cortical bone expansion in both tibiae and fibulae. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Normal calcium, Normal phosphorus, High ALP

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the structure of the sarcomere using skeletal muscle obtained from an experimental animal. He develops monoclonal antibodies directed against a specific skeletal muscle protein and finds that these antibodies disrupt the binding of actin to structural support elements within the sarcomere. Which of the following labeled regions do these antibodies most likely bind?
questions.solution: Ans. A) A

questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50ml/hr

 

Insensible water loss refers to water lost through skin (evaporation, not sweating) and respiratory tract.

 

Normal insensible water loss is ~500–700 ml/day, which averages to ~50 ml/hr in adults.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. 100 ml/hr: Too high (would be ~2.4 L/day, above normal range).
 

Option B. 150 ml/hr: Very high, exceeds physiologic baseline loss.
 

Option D. 200 ml/hr: Extremely high, pathological rather than normal.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man participates in a research study. He undergoes percutaneous skeletal muscle biopsy. Microscopic analysis shows his type I and type II muscle fibers are clustered in groups in contrast to a normal intermixed pattern, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the changes observed in this patient’s skeletal muscle?

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of the observed findings on histology?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Motor axon degeneration and reinnervation

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic with recurrent nausea, bloating, and early satiety for the past 3 months. She reports occasional vomiting of undigested food several hours after eating. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus with long-standing poor glycemic control and associated neuropathy. Physical examination reveals a soft, non-tender abdomen with normal bowel sounds. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy shows no structural abnormalities. A macrolide is prescribed after which patient reports significant improvement in her symptoms. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for this patient's improvement?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Agonistic activity on motilin receptors

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset, severe left flank pain that radiates to his groin. He has a history of hypertension and atherosclerosis. His blood pressure is 152/90 mm Hg, pulse is 100/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. A contrast-enhanced CT scan reveals a wedge-shaped perfusion defect in the left kidney, consistent with a renal infarct. Which of the following histologic changes is most likely to occur in the affected renal tissue over the next several days?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Coagulative necrosis

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to worsening cough over the past several months. She initially experienced a dry cough, but now it has become productive with large amounts of yellowish sputum. The patient also complains of breathlessness on moderate exertion. She has had two hospitalizations this year for respiratory infections. The patient has a significant history of smoking one pack per day for the past 35 years and has made multiple unsuccessful attempts to quit. Her oxygen saturation is 89% at rest and decreases to 84% with moderate exertion. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Increased erythropoietin production

questions.text:
A previously healthy 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a one-week history of diffuse abdominal pain. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). Physical examination shows numerous scars and excoriations along both arms, scleral icterus, and tender hepatomegaly. Serum studies shown below:

 

 

Which of the following is least likely to be seen in the liver biopsy of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ground glass hepatocytes

 

  • Acute Hepatitis B infection: Biopsy shows ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes, spotty/focal necrosis, Councilman bodies (apoptotic hepatocytes), and confluent necrosis in severe cases.
  • Ground glass hepatocytes are a feature of chronic Hepatitis B infection due to HBsAg accumulation in hepatocyte endoplasmic reticulum.
  • Since the patient is in acute hepatitis (anti-HBc negative → very early), ground glass cells will not be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ballooning degeneration: Common in acute hepatitis, due to hepatocyte swelling and cytoskeletal damage.

 

Option C. Focal or spotty necrosis: Hallmark of acute viral hepatitis → scattered hepatocyte necrosis with lymphocytic infiltration.

 

Option D. Confluent necrosis of hepatocytes: Severe form in acute viral hepatitis, may progress to bridging necrosis and liver failure.

choices.text: Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI-reabsorption, passive K+ secretion , active secretion of HCO3-
Passive Na+ reabsorption, active CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-
Passive Na+ secretion, active CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-
Active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

questions.text: The second phase of saliva secretion involves:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

choices.text: Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate
Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate→ Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release
Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal
Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens

questions.text: Identify the correct order of End plate potential at the neuromuscular junction:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

Explanation:

 

At the neuromuscular junction (NMJ), the sequence of events leading to muscle contraction begins with the binding of acetylcholine (Ach) to its receptors on the motor end plate. This binding opens ligand-gated Na⁺ channels, allowing an influx of sodium ions, which depolarizes the muscle membrane and generates an action potential. The action potential travels along the motor neuron to the axon terminal, where it triggers the opening of voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels. The entry of calcium ions into the axon terminal facilitates the exocytosis of Ach into the synaptic cleft, which then binds to receptors on the muscle fiber to propagate the signal for muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release:
This sequence incorrectly initiates with the opening of ligand-gated Na⁺ channels before Ach is released. In reality, Ach must first be released to bind to these channels and cause their opening. 

 

Option C. Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal:
Ach release is a result of Ca²⁺ entry, not the initial step. This option reverses the correct order of events.

 

Option D. Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens:
This sequence incorrectly places the action potential at the motor end plate before Ach release. The action potential at the motor end plate is a result of Ach binding, not the precursor to Ca²⁺ entry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence at the neuromuscular junction is:

 

Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma comes to the clinic for follow-up. She recently completed a round of chemotherapy. Immunohistochemistry confirms these cells are undergoing apoptosis. Which of the following substances, released from mitochondria, most likely initiated the observed cellular changes?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Cytochrome c

questions.text:
Which of the following sodium transporters are present maximally in early part of PCT?

 

  1. Na-K-ATPase
  2. Na-glucose cotransport
  3. Na-H antiporter
  4. Na-HCO3 symporter
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

 

  • In early PCT, sodium is reabsorbed with glucose (SGLT), via Na-H exchanger, and Na-K-ATPase drives the process.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 3, 4, 1: Includes HCO3 symporter, which is more distal.

 

Option B. 4, 2: Incomplete set.

 

Option D. 1, 4: Misses glucose and H+ exchange.

questions.text: A 25 yr old women G2P1L1 is brought to the emergency at 30 weeks gestation in active labor. The patient had severe anemia during pregnancy and received multiple blood transfusions during past months. An uncomplicated Vaginal delivery is performed and 2.5 kg infant is delivered. Post operatively she continues to bleed and receives a transfusion of 1 unit of packed RBC. One hour later, the patient appears to have flank pain and in acute distress. Temperature is 101°F, pulse 115/min and BP is 92/66 mm Hg. Foley catheter shows dark brown urine. Further evaluation is most likely to show:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Positive Direct Coomb’s

 

  • The patient developed symptoms of an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (fever, flank pain, hypotension, dark brown urine shortly after transfusion).
  • This reaction is usually due to antibodies against red blood cell antigens from a previous sensitization, causing immune-mediated destruction of transfused RBCs.
  • The Direct Coombs test (direct antiglobulin test) detects antibodies or complement bound to RBCs and would be positive in this setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum antibodies against Class 1 HLA: Serum antibodies against Class 1 HLA are associated with febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions, not acute hemolysis.

 

Option C. B/L pulmonary infiltrates on CXR: Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates indicate transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), a different complication.

 

Option D. Low levels of serum IgA: Low serum IgA is related to anaphylactic transfusion reactions in IgA-deficient patients, which present differently.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to confusion, abdominal pain, and vomiting for the past two days. Her parents report that she has been excessively thirsty and urinating frequently over the last few weeks. On examination, her vital signs are as follows: temperature 37.2°C (99°F), pulse 110/min, blood pressure 90/60 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 28/min. Laboratory investigations reveal the following:

 

  • Glucose 320 mg/dL
  • Sodium 132 meq/l
  • Potassium 5.2 meq/l
  • Bicarbonate 12 meq/l
  • Arterial pH 7.25
  • Urinalysis: Positive for urine and ketones

 

Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the development of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Islet leukocytic infiltration

 

This patient has type 1 diabetes with DKA, where autoimmune islet leukocytic infiltration destroys beta cells, leading to insulin deficiency and ketosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive caloric intake does not directly cause DKA.

 

Option B. HLA polymorphisms increase susceptibility but are not the direct cause of acute DKA.

 

Option C. Beta-cell amyloid deposition is associated with type 2 diabetes, not type 1.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up one month after a stroke that resulted in speech difficulties. The patient’s speech is fluent with appropriate cadence, but she is unable to correctly repeat phrases that the physician verbalizes. She can follow 2- and 3-step commands without difficulty. Which of the following brain regions is most likely impaired in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Arcuate fasciculus

questions.text: An 18-month-old girls has developed seborrheic skin eruptions over the past 3 months. She has had recurrent upper respiratory and middle ear infections with streptococcus pneumoniae for the past year. Physical examination indicates that she also has hepatosplenomegaly and generalized lymphadenopathy. Her hearing is reduced in the right ear. A skull radiograph shows an expansile, 2 cm lytic lesion involving the right temporal bone. Laboratory studies show no anemia, thrombocytopenia, or leukopenia. The mass is curetted. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on microscopic examination of this mass?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Histocytes with Birbeck granules

questions.text: A man who is fond of exotic cuisine develops perioral numbness after eating the pufferfish. The given poisoning is due to which of the following toxins?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Tetrodotoxin

questions.text: Erythropoietin is produced by all of the following organs except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Spleen

questions.text: A 38-year-old weightlifter is competing in a powerlifting championship. After successfully lifting a barbell weighing 200 kg, he holds the weight for a few seconds before his arms suddenly give way, and he drops the weight involuntarily. The lifter does not experience pain, and his arms feel weak but recover quickly. This sudden muscle relaxation was most likely initiated by which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Golgi tendon organs

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was referred to a pediatric endocrinologist because of growth retardation. Lab tests showed increased serum growth hormone levels but very low serum levels of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1). Further exams led to the diagnosis of Laron dwarfism. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for this boy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mecasermin

 

Mecasermin is recombinant IGF-1 and is the treatment of choice for Laron dwarfism, where GH receptor defects cause low IGF-1 despite high GH levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Somatropin: Ineffective as GH receptors are defective in Laron dwarfism.

 

Option B. Octreotide: A somatostatin analogue that inhibits GH secretion, not useful here.

 

Option D. Oxandrolone: An anabolic steroid not used for treating growth hormone receptor defects.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with progressive facial puffiness and lower extremity edema over the past 2 months. Laboratory studies reveal serum creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL, albumin level of 2.7 g/dL, and 3+ proteinuria on urinalysis. A kidney biopsy is performed, and light microscopy with hematoxylin and eosin staining is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s kidney findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Diabetes mellitus

choices.text: Cortisol low, Aldosterone low, ADH high, Norepinephrine high
Cortisol normal, Aldosterone low, ADH normal, Norepinephrine normal
Cortisol low, Aldosterone low, ADH normal, Norepinephrine normal
Cortisol high, Aldosterone low, ADH high, Norepinephrine high

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of fatigue, weight loss, salt craving, and dizziness upon standing. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Her mother was recently diagnosed with hypothyroidism. On examination, her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg supine and 80/50 mm Hg standing. Laboratory results reveal the following:

 

Sodium 129 meq/l 

 

Potassium 5.9 meq/l 

 

Chloride 100 meq/l 

 

Bicarbonate 21 meq/l 

 

Creatinine 1.4 mg/dl 

 

BUN 38 mg/dl 

 

Which of the following in circulating hormone levels are expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cortisol low, Aldosterone low, ADH high, Norepinephrine high

 

This patient has primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s disease) indicated by fatigue, weight loss, salt craving, hypotension, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Cortisol and aldosterone are both low, leading to hypotension and volume depletion. Compensatory mechanisms increase ADH and norepinephrine to maintain blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cortisol normal, Aldosterone low, ADH normal, Norepinephrine normal: Cortisol would be low, not normal, and compensatory hormones would be elevated.

 

Option C. Cortisol low, Aldosterone low, ADH normal, Norepinephrine normal: ADH rises in response to hypotension and hyponatremia; norepinephrine is also elevated.

 

Option D. Cortisol high, Aldosterone low, ADH high, Norepinephrine high: Cortisol is not high in adrenal insufficiency; high cortisol would suppress ADH and norepinephrine.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath, productive cough, and fatigue for the past 5 days. His medical history includes heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and chronic hypertension. On physical examination, dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds are noted over the left lower lung. Chest X-ray is shown. Thoracentesis is performed, and the results are as follows:

 

 

 

Which of the following is most likely contributing to the pathogenesis of this patient's pleural effusion?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Increased inflammatory pleural permeability

questions.text: Physiologists studying hemoglobin function in patients with respiratory disorders are evaluating changes associated with oxygen loading and unloading. During the transition from point 1 to point 2 on the graph shown below, hemoglobin molecules are most likely to release which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Protons 

 

During oxygen unloading (from point 1 to point 2 on the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve), hemoglobin releases protons (H+), which contribute to the Bohr effect facilitating oxygen release in tissues. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Chloride: Chloride ions (chloride shift) enter red blood cells during CO2 transport but are not directly released during oxygen unloading. 

 

Option B. Oxygen: Oxygen is released by hemoglobin, but the question asks which molecule is released by hemoglobin apart from oxygen during this transition. 

 

Option C. Phosphate: Phosphate 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate binds to deoxygenated hemoglobin but is not released during oxygen unloading.

choices.text: Distal convoluted tubule - Generation of ammonia
Distal convoluted tubule - Reabsorption of bicarbonate
Distal convoluted tubule - Secretion of hydrogen ions
Proximal convoluted tubule - Reabsorption of bicarbonate

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to failure to thrive, frequent urination, and excessive thirst. Examination shows frontal bossing, delayed growth, and mild muscle weakness. Laboratory studies reveal hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, glucosuria, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following structure/function combinations is most likely defective in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Proximal convoluted tubule - Reabsorption of bicarbonate

choices.text: Saline washed RBC: Increased risk of allergic reaction

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly matched:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cryo-poor plasma: TTP 

 

  • Cryo-poor plasma (cryosupernatant) is plasma from which cryoprecipitate has been removed. It contains ADAMTS13 enzyme and is used in the treatment of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) to replenish ADAMTS13 and correct the deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FFP: Hemophilia A: Hemophilia A is treated with factor VIII concentrate or cryoprecipitate, not FFP routinely.

 

Option B. Saline washed RBC: Increased risk of allergic reaction: Washing reduces allergic reactions, so they lower, not increase, the risk.

 

Option C. Cryoprecipitate: Hemophilia B: Hemophilia B (factor IX deficiency) requires factor IX concentrate or FFP, not cryoprecipitate.

choices.text: CD14 on macrophages with bacterial lipopolysaccharide
CD16 on NK cells with IgG-coated infected cells
CD18 on neutrophils with ICAM-1 on endothelial cells
CD28 on T lymphocytes with CD80/86 on epidermal dendritic cells

questions.text: A 28-year-old medical student undergoes a tuberculin skin test (TST) as part of a routine health check. He is asymptomatic with no history of recent fever, weight loss, or cough. He receives an intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD) on the inner surface of his forearm. After 48 hours, a raised, erythematous induration measuring 18 mm is observed at the injection site. Which of the following interactions is critical to the development of this patient’s skin reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CD28 on T lymphocytes with CD80/86 on epidermal dendritic cells

 

The TST is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction mediated by CD4+ T-cells. Interaction of CD28 on T-cells with CD80/86 on antigen-presenting dendritic cells provides the costimulatory signal essential for T-cell activation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. CD14 on macrophages with bacterial lipopolysaccharide: Involved in innate immune response to Gram-negative bacteria, not delayed-type hypersensitivity.

 

Option B. CD16 on NK cells with IgG-coated infected cells: Mediates antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC), not TST reaction.

 

Option C. CD18 on neutrophils with ICAM-1 on endothelial cells: Involved in leukocyte adhesion and migration, not the critical T-cell activation in TST.

questions.text: Thalidomide should not be used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HIV-assosiated peripheral neuropathy 

 

  •  Thalidomide is contraindicated in peripheral neuropathy because it can worsen or precipitate neuropathic damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HIV-associated aphthous ulcers: Thalidomide has been used for treatment of severe, refractory aphthous ulcers in HIV patients.


Option C. Behçet syndrome: Effective in treating severe mucocutaneous manifestations and oral/genital ulcers.


Option D. Erythema nodosum leprosum: One of the main indications for thalidomide, where it provides dramatic improvement.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with facial swelling and difficulty swallowing. He reports waking up with swelling of his lips and tongue, along with a sensation of throat tightness.  He recently started taking enalapril for hypertension 1 month ago. He has no history of allergies or similar symptoms in the past. On examination, there is no wheezing or urticaria. Vital signs are stable. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Excess bradykinin accumulation

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after fainting at home. She has been experiencing severe thirst and frequent urination for several days. Her medical history is significant for a traumatic brain injury two weeks ago from a motor vehicle accident.  Her fluid volume and osmolality changes are shown below. The solid line represents a normal individual, and the dotted line represents this patient. Which of the following conditions is most likely causing this patient’s findings?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Diabetes insipidus

questions.text: Sodium iodide symport is present in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pituitary

 

The sodium iodide symporter is responsible for iodide uptake in thyroid, salivary gland, and placenta but is not present in the pituitary gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Placenta: Has sodium iodide symporter to actively transport iodide to the fetus.

 

Option C. Salivary gland: Expresses the symporter for iodide concentration in saliva.

 

Option D. Thyroid: The primary site of sodium iodide symporter expression for thyroid hormone synthesis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressive shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. He has a history of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis, for which he previously took methotrexate but stopped treatment a year ago. He denies tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use. On physical examination, the patient has end-inspiratory crackles at the lung bases and no wheezing.  A chest X-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s pulmonary symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman has experienced pain in the area around the left knee for the past 6 weeks. MRI shows a well-circumscribed 4-cm mass superior and inferior to the patella. The mass is within soft tissue, without bony erosion. A biopsy of the mass is obtained and on microscopic examination shows a biphasic pattern of spindle cells and epithelial cells forming glands. Karyotypic analysis of tumor cells shows a t(X;18) translocation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Synovial sarcoma

 

Characterized by biphasic pattern (spindle cells + epithelial gland-like structures) and t(X;18) translocation, most common near large joints in young to middle-aged adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desmoid tumor: Fibroblastic proliferation, locally aggressive, no glandular structures or t(X;18).

 

Option B. Leiomyosarcoma: Malignant smooth muscle tumor, shows fascicles of spindle cells with blunt-ended nuclei, no biphasic pattern or translocation.

 

Option C. Mesothelioma: Malignancy of pleura/peritoneum, not localized to knee, no specific t(X;18).

questions.text: A 26-year-old man developed sudden severe abdominal pain. On physical examination, he had marked abdominal tenderness and guarding. Laboratory studies showed calcium-12.2 mg/dL; phosphorus-2.6 mg/ dL; creatinine, 1.1 mg/dL; and parathyroid hormone-62 pg/mL (normal: 9-60 pg/mL). During surgery, four enlarged parathyroid glands were found and excised, with re-implantation of one half of one gland. After the surgery, his calcium concentration returned to normal. Three years later, he had an episode of upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage. An endoscopy and biopsy specimen showed multiple benign gastric ulcerations. Abdominal MRI indicated multiple 1- to 2-cm mass lesions in the pancreas. Which of the following additional neoplasm lesions is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pituitary adenoma

 

This patient likely has Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN1), characterized by parathyroid hyperplasia, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, and pituitary adenomas. Pituitary adenoma is the common third tumor. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Adrenal pheochromocytoma: Typical of MEN2, not MEN1. 

 

Option B. Endometrial carcinoma: Not associated with MEN syndromes. 

 

Option D. Thyroid medullary carcinoma: Characteristic of MEN2, not MEN1.

questions.text: 71-year-old man has had decreased urine output <500 mL per day for the past 3 days. Physical examination shows vital signs with temperature 37° C, pulse 88/min, respiratory rate 18/min, and blood pressure 85/60 mm Hg. He has peripheral edema and diffuse rales on auscultation of the chest. Urinalysis shows specific gravity 1.019 and no protein, blood, glucose, ketones, WBCs, RBCs, or casts. His serum creatinine is 3.3 mg/dL, and urea nitrogen is 62 mg/dL. The fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) is <1%. Which of the following underlying conditions is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dilated cardiomyopathy

 

  • The patient has features of prerenal azotemia (low BP, FENa <1%, high BUN/Cr ratio) due to reduced effective arterial blood volume.
  • The presence of edema and pulmonary congestion suggests heart failure, most likely due to dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Membranous nephropathy: Causes nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria, not seen here.

 

Option C. ATN: Would show FENa >2% and muddy brown casts, absent here.

 

Option D. Urothelial carcinoma: Presents with hematuria, not prerenal failure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to progressive lethargy, fatigue, and nausea over the past month. questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with diet and exercise undergoes treadmill stress testing for complaints of intermittent fatigue. He reports no chest pain during the test but stops after 6 minutes due to exertional 

 

  • Vitals:
    • Resting heart rate: 72/min; peak stress heart rate: 138/min
    • Resting blood pressure: 120/75 mm Hg; peak stress: 135/82 mm Hg.
  • ECG shows normal sinus rhythm without ischemic changes.
  • Physical exam and echocardiogram at rest are unremarkable.

 

During exercise, which of the following hemodynamic parameters is most likely to be decreased compared to the resting state?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total systemic vascular resistance

 

During exercise, vasodilation occurs in the skeletal muscles to increase blood flow, which leads to a decrease in total systemic vascular resistance (SVR).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac output: Despite decreased SVR, cardiac output increases due to increased heart rate and stroke volume, resulting in increased systolic blood pressure.

 

Option B. Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure: Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure may slightly increase or stay the same due to increased venous return.

 

Option C. Systemic systolic blood pressure: Systemic systolic blood pressure typically increases during exercise due to increased cardiac output.

Option C. Decreased sodium absorption in PCT: True effect of ANP.

 

Option D. Inhibition of sodium reabsorption in medullary collecting duct: Also true effect.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old woman recently discharged from the hospital after being treated for acute pyelonephritis returns for a follow-up visit. She complains of poor appetite and fatigue but notes that her urinary symptoms have resolved. Her laboratory findings include:

Creatinine: 1.7 mg/dL

questions.solution: Ans. C) Prerenal azotemia

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting and seizures. On examination blood pressure is 220/110 mm Hg. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for managing his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV Labetalol

 

  • The patient has a hypertensive emergency with signs of hypertensive encephalopathy (headache, confusion, seizures, visual disturbances) and very high blood pressure (220/110 mm Hg).
  • In hypertensive emergencies, intravenous antihypertensives with rapid onset but controlled lowering of blood pressure are required.
  • IV Labetalol is a commonly used, effective agent that lowers BP quickly without significant cerebral blood flow reduction.
  • Oral agents like nifedipine or nicardipine capsules are too slow or inappropriate for emergencies.
  • IV nitroglycerin mainly dilates veins and is generally used for acute coronary syndrome or pulmonary edema, not primary hypertensive encephalopathy.

 

Thus, IV labetalol is the most appropriate choice.The correct answer is A. Cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Anticancer drug that can result in hand and foot syndrome is:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Capecitabine

choices.text: Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 50% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus
Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus
Ruptured atherosclerotic plaque with fully obstructive thrombus
Significant coronary artery vasospasm causing flow obstruction

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to severe central chest pain that started a few hours ago. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, and V1–V4, along with deep Q wave formation over the next several hours. Cardiac catheterization would most likely reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ruptured atherosclerotic plaque with fully obstructive thrombus

 

  • The ECG findings show ST elevation in leads I, aVL, and V1–V4 with evolving deep Q waves, consistent with an acute anterolateral ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).
  • Acute STEMI usually results from rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque, leading to thrombus formation that fully obstructs the coronary artery lumen.
  • Cardiac catheterization during acute MI typically reveals a fully occlusive thrombus over a ruptured plaque.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 50% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus and Option B. Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus: Plaques causing 50% or 80% stenosis without thrombus typically cause stable angina or no acute MI.

 

Option D. Significant coronary artery vasospasm causing flow obstruction: Vasospasm causes transient obstruction and usually does not cause persistent ST elevation with Q waves.

questions.text: Calcium binds to which one of the following proteins in smooth muscle contraction:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Calmodulin

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is admitted to the hospital due to worsening dyspnea and fatigue. He has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).  The patient is started on oral digoxin for rate control. A week later, his serum digoxin level is measured and found to be markedly elevated, despite receiving an appropriate dose. Upon further questioning, it is discovered that the patient was recently started on amiodarone. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the interaction between the drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibition of P-glycoprotein

 

  • Amiodarone inhibits P-glycoprotein, a transporter involved in the efflux of digoxin from the kidneys and intestines.
  • Inhibition of P-glycoprotein by amiodarone decreases digoxin clearance, leading to increased serum digoxin levels and a higher risk of digoxin toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blockade of biliary transport proteins: Not involved in digoxin elimination.

 

Option B. Induction of cytochrome P-450 enzymes: Amiodarone is actually an inhibitor, not an inducer, and digoxin is not metabolized significantly by CYP enzymes.

 

Option D. Stimulation of Na+/K+-ATPase: Digoxin inhibits this pump; stimulation would be opposite and unrelated to drug interactions.

choices.text: Increase in a vasomotor centre activity
Increase in the discharge of carotid sinus afferent nerves
Decreased heart rate and blood pressure

questions.text: Below (proximal) the carotid sinus, carotid artery clamping is likely to result in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in a vasomotor centre activity

 

  • Clamping the carotid artery below the carotid sinus reduces blood flow to the sinus baroreceptors, causing decreased baroreceptor firing (afferent nerve discharge).
  • This reduction in baroreceptor signals leads to disinhibition of the vasomotor center in the brainstem, causing increased sympathetic activity to raise heart rate and blood pressure as a compensatory response.
  • Therefore, vasomotor center activity increases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in discharge of carotid sinus afferent nerves: Clamping decreases carotid sinus pressure and thus decreases afferent firing.

 

Option C. Decreased heart rate and blood pressure: Reduced baroreceptor firing stimulates sympathetic outflow, increasing heart rate and BP.

 

Option D. Baroreceptor adaptation: Is a long-term resetting, not an immediate response to arterial clamping.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the clinic for follow-up after thyroid surgery. Four months ago, he underwent a total thyroidectomy followed by radioactive iodine ablation for papillary thyroid carcinoma. He was prescribed levothyroxine for thyroid hormone replacement therapy. Over the past month, the patient has experienced palpitations, tremors, weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lb), and excessive sweating. He denies heat or cold intolerance and notes compliance with his medication regimen. On examination, his temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg, and pulse is 112/min. questions.text: In an experiment investigating vasoconstriction of the arterial wall, two samples of isolated porcine arterial vessels are studied. Vascular tone is measured in the control vessel during infusion of increasing doses of norepinephrine. The other vessel is pretreated with experimental drug A prior to infusion of norepinephrine. A graph of the study results is depicted below. Drug A is most similar to which of the following agents?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Phenoxybenzamine

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a long history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the clinic complaining of dizziness and weakness in his left arm when performing activities like playing table tennis. He has been a chronic smoker for over 40 years. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm, and orthostatic vital signs are normal. A Doppler ultrasound of the left vertebral artery shows retrograde flow instead of normal antegrade flow. Which of the following arteries is most likely stenosed or occluded to cause these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left subclavian artery

 

  • The patient has subclavian steal syndrome, characterized by symptoms of arm ischemia (dizziness and weakness with arm exertion) and retrograde flow in the vertebral artery on Doppler ultrasound.
  • This occurs due to proximal stenosis or occlusion of the left subclavian artery before the origin of the vertebral artery.
  • Blood flow reverses in the ipsilateral vertebral artery to supply the arm, causing vertebrobasilar insufficiency symptoms (dizziness) and arm ischemia during exertion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left internal carotid artery: Causes cerebral ischemia but does not cause retrograde vertebral artery flow.

 

Option B. Left vertebral artery: Occlusion here would reduce vertebral flow but wouldn't cause retrograde flow.

 

Option D. Right subclavian artery: Would cause symptoms on the right side, not left.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with sudden-onset palpitations and lightheadedness while playing video games. He states this has occurred intermittently over the past year, but the episodes typically resolve spontaneously after a few minutes. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. ECG is shown below. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accessory pathway bypassing the AV node

 

  • The patient's presentation of sudden-onset palpitations with intermittent episodes that resolve spontaneously, along with characteristic ECG findings (likely showing short PR interval and delta waves), suggests Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome.
  • WPW is caused by an accessory conduction pathway (bundle of Kent) that bypasses the AV node, allowing premature ventricular activation.
  • This accessory pathway can facilitate a reentrant tachycardia causing paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), explaining the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Degeneration of AV conduction system: Typically causes heart block in older patients, not paroxysmal tachycardias in young people.

 

Option C. Ectopic atrial pacemaker activity: Causes atrial tachycardia but does not explain delta waves or WPW ECG pattern.

 

Option D. SA node dysfunction: Causes bradycardia, not tachycardia or reentrant arrhythmias.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the variability in drug metabolism across individuals using isoniazid. Variation in which of the following metabolic processes is the most likely explanation for this observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acetylation

 

The graph shows a bimodal distribution of plasma isoniazid (INH) concentrations among individuals, representing populations of slow and fast acetylators. Acetylation is mediated by the N-acetyltransferase enzyme, which exhibits genetic polymorphism leading to classification of individuals as slow or fast acetylators, directly explaining the bimodal plasma concentrations of isoniazid. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylation: Methylation is a phase II metabolic reaction that involves transferring a methyl group to substrates, often leading to detoxification or alteration of activity. While methylation occurs with many drugs, it is not the primary pathway responsible for the variability in isoniazid metabolism or plasma concentration differences seen in populations.

 

Option B. Hydrolysis: Hydrolysis involves cleavage of chemical bonds through the addition of water, commonly seen in ester or amide bonds. This reaction is important for activating or deactivating some drugs, but it is not a significant metabolic pathway for isoniazid, hence not contributing to its variable plasma levels.

 

Option D. Glucuronidation: Glucuronidation is a major phase II conjugation reaction that attaches glucuronic acid to lipophilic molecules to enhance excretion. It typically affects drugs like morphine or bilirubin but is not the key metabolic step for isoniazid nor responsible for its polymorphic metabolism.

choices.text: Decreased renal perfusion, decreased intraglomerular pressure, and decreased filtration fraction
Increased  renal perfusion, decreased intraglomerular pressure, and decreased filtration fraction
Decreased renal perfusion, increased intraglomerular pressure, and decreased filtration fraction

questions.text: Which of the following changes are most likely to occur in this patient’s kidney function after starting therapy with lisinopril?

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to shortness of breath, poor appetite, and abdominal distension for the past 3 months. His symptoms have progressively worsened, and he is now unable to perform his daily activities. The patient has a history of ischemic heart disease and underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 5 years ago. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, abdominal distension, hepatomegaly, and bilateral lower extremity edema. A representative liver biopsy image is shown in the exhibit. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s liver findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Passive hepatic congestion

 

The clinical picture (chronic right-sided heart failure signs: JVD, hepatomegaly, ascites, peripheral edema) plus biopsy consistent with centrilobular (zone 3) congestion and sinusoidal dilatation (nutmeg liver) indicates chronic passive hepatic congestion due to congestive heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune biliary destruction: Primary biliary cholangitis shows portal-based duct injury and antimitochondrial antibodies, not centrilobular congestion.

 

Option B. Excessive deposition of iron: Hemochromatosis causes diffuse hepatocellular iron pigment and eventual micronodular cirrhosis, not the pattern of venous congestion.

 

Option C. Hepatitis virus infection: Viral hepatitis produces lobular inflammation and hepatocellular necrosis/portal interface activity rather than passive sinusoidal congestion.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents due to fatigue, easy bruising, and frequent nosebleeds for 2 weeks. On physical examination, the child appears pale with scattered petechiae. Laboratory studies show:

 

Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL

 

Platelet count: 21,000/mm³

 

Leukocyte count: 15,500/mm³

 

A bone marrow aspirate reveals the findings shown in the image below. The cells are positive for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) and express CD19 and CD10. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Precursor B-cell leukemia 

 

  • The child's symptoms (fatigue, bruising, nosebleeds), laboratory findings (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis), and bone marrow aspirate indicate acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
  • Positivity for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) and expression of CD19 and CD10 are characteristic markers of precursor B-cell ALL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Precursor T-cell leukemia: Precursor T-cell leukemia expresses markers like CD3 and lacks CD19.

 

Option C. Mature B-cell leukemia and D. Mature T-cell leukemia: Mature B-cell or T-cell leukemias would not express TdT.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for recurrent nosebleeds. The mother reports that the boy has had five nosebleeds within the past 2 weeks, each lasting between 15 and 20 minutes. The patient was born at term and has been hospitalized twice for pneumonia treatment. There is no family history of serious illness. The patient is at the 8th percentile for height and the 30th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a small, thin child with two flat, dark brown areas of hyperpigmentation across the upper back and a similar discoloration on the left buttock. There is bilateral esotropia. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.3 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 107 um3, leukocyte count of 3800/mm3, and platelet count of 46,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defect in DNA crosslink repair

 

The patient most likely has Fanconi anemia, caused by defects in DNA crosslink repair. It presents with pancytopenia, congenital anomalies, café-au-lait spots, and growth retardation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Mutation in WAS protein: Causes Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome; features include small platelets, eczema, and recurrent infections, but not congenital anomalies like café-au-lait spots.

 

Option C. Acute Lymphoblastic leukemia: Usually presents with blast cells on peripheral smear, rapid onset, and bone pain; not typical congenital anomalies.

 

Option D. Post Viral Autoimmune reaction: Usually causes isolated cytopenias transiently, not multiple congenital anomalies or chronic pancytopenia.

Option D. Autoimmune -ve dysglycemic presymptomatic: Not typical of Type 1 DM where autoimmunity drives dysglycemia.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the structure and function of immunoglobulins that are transmitted across the placenta from mother to fetus. The structure indicated by the arrow is primarily responsible for which of the following immunological events?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fixing of complement

 

The arrow points to the Fc region of the IgG molecule. This part of the antibody is primarily responsible for fixing complement via the classical pathway, allowing activation of immune effector functions such as cell lysis and phagocytosis.

 

Fc = helps in placental transfer, It binds specifically to the neonatal Fc receptor (FcRn) expressed on placental syncytiotrophoblast cells

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Formation of dimer: This is characteristic of IgA, not IgG.

 

Option B. Binding to mast cells: Mostly associated with IgE.

 

Option D. Attachment to antigen: Occurs at the Fab region, not the Fc region.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the clinic with 2 months of worsening fatigue and persistent lower back pain that is aggravated by movement. Physical examination shows pallor and tenderness over the lower spine. Radiographic imaging reveals lytic bone lesions. Laboratory findings include:

 

Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL

Serum creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL

Serum calcium: 11.0 mg/dL

 

Urine dipstick is negative for protein, but 24-hour urine protein quantification shows elevated protein levels. Urine electrophoresis is most likely to detect which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lambda light chains

 

  • The patient's presentation of fatigue, anemia, back pain with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal dysfunction is classic for multiple myeloma.
  • Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy producing excess monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains (either kappa or lambda).
  • These free light chains are filtered by the kidney and appear in the urine as Bence Jones proteins.
  • Urine electrophoresis in multiple myeloma typically detects excess free light chains (kappa or lambda) rather than intact immunoglobulins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gamma heavy chains: Gamma heavy chains are seen in heavy chain diseases, which are rare.

 

Option B. Immunoglobulin G and C. Immunoglobulin M: Immunoglobulin G or M refers to intact immunoglobulins, which typically show up in serum electrophoresis rather than urine.

questions.text: Which point in the following diagram indicates that the left ventricular pressure is equivalent to the diastolic blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) b

 

  • On the left ventricular pressure-volume loop, point b indicates the point where the aortic valve opens. This occurs when left ventricular pressure first exceeds the aortic (diastolic) pressure, allowing ejection to begin.
  • Thus, at point b, left ventricular pressure is equal to the diastolic blood pressure of the aorta.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. a: Mitral valve closes (end-diastolic volume, start of systole)

 

Option C. c: Aortic valve closes (end-systolic volume)

 

Option D. d: Mitral valve opens (start of ventricular filling)
