questions.text: Which of the following growth hormone analogue that is not used for treatment of GH deficiency but is used in the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tesamorelin

 

Tesamorelin is a synthetic analogue of growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) that is specifically used in the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy, a condition characterized by abnormal distribution of body fat in patients with HIV. Tesamorelin reduces visceral adipose tissue and improves the body composition of individuals with this condition. Unlike other growth hormone analogues, Tesamorelin is not primarily used for treating growth hormone deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sermorelin: Sermorelin is a synthetic analogue of GHRH used to diagnose and treat growth hormone deficiency. It is not indicated for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Option C. Somatropin: Somatropin is a recombinant form of human growth hormone used to treat growth hormone deficiencies. It is not used for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Option D. Pegvisomant: Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly. It is not used for HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tesamorelin is a growth hormone-releasing hormone analogue used specifically for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy, distinguishing it from other growth hormone analogues that are used for treating growth hormone deficiencies.

choices.text: Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate

questions.text: Why is atropine mixed with diphenoxylate in combination medications? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To prevent abuse of diphenoxylate

 

Diphenoxylate is an opioid used to treat diarrhea by slowing down bowel movements. However, like other opioids, it carries a risk of abuse, especially if taken in large doses. Atropine, an anticholinergic drug, is mixed with diphenoxylate in subtherapeutic doses to deter misuse. When taken as prescribed, the amount of atropine is too small to cause significant effects. However, if someone tries to abuse diphenoxylate by taking a large number of tablets, the atropine will also accumulate and cause unpleasant side effects such as dry mouth, urinary retention, and blurred vision. These side effects are uncomfortable and discourage further abuse of the medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate: This is incorrect because atropine is not added to decrease the adverse effects of diphenoxylate. In fact, when taken in large doses, atropine can add to the side effects rather than diminish them.

 

Option C. To enhance the antidiarrheal effect: While atropine also has anticholinergic properties that can reduce gastrointestinal motility, it is not added for this purpose in the combination. The primary reason for its inclusion is to prevent abuse, not to enhance the antidiarrheal effect.

 

Option D. Atropine produces direct spasmolytic action: Although atropine can reduce spasms in the gastrointestinal tract, it is not included in this combination for its spasmolytic action. The dose of atropine used is subtherapeutic and does not significantly contribute to spasmolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine is added to diphenoxylate to prevent the abuse of the opioid component by causing unpleasant side effects if the medication is taken in large doses, thereby discouraging misuse.

choices.text: Oral candidiasis is common with its use.
It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids.
It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase.
It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ciclesonide is incorrect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis is common with its use.

 

Ciclesonide is an inhalational corticosteroid used to manage asthma and other respiratory conditions.

 

It is unique among inhaled corticosteroids because it is a "soft steroid" and functions as a prodrug. This means that Ciclesonide is inactive when administered and only becomes active when it reaches the lungs, where it is converted into its active form by bronchial esterases. This activation in the target site, the bronchial airways, significantly reduces the drug's systemic side effects, including the risk of oral candidiasis, which is common with other inhaled corticosteroids.

 

Because the majority of the drug that deposits in the oropharynx remains inactive, the likelihood of developing oral candidiasis (a common side effect of other inhalational steroids due to local immunosuppression) is significantly lower with Ciclesonide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids: This statement is correct. Due to its activation in the bronchial tree, Ciclesonide has fewer systemic and local side effects compared to other inhalational corticosteroids.

 

Option C. It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase: This is also correct. Ciclesonide remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is converted into its active form by bronchial esterases.

 

Option D. It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids: This is correct. Ciclesonide is just as effective as other inhalational corticosteroids in managing respiratory conditions such as asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciclesonide, a prodrug inhalational corticosteroid, has a lower risk of causing oral candidiasis compared to other inhalational steroids because it remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is activated by bronchial esterases.

questions.text: An elderly male presented to the clinic with fatigue, headache, backache, and renal dysfunction. He had elevated calcium levels also. His serum electrophoresis had an M spike and the immunofixation pattern has been presented alongside. What is the likely diagnosis in the patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multiple myeloma with elevated IgM

 

The clinical presentation of an elderly male with fatigue, headache, backache, renal dysfunction, and hypercalcemia is suggestive of a plasma cell disorder, such as multiple myeloma. The key diagnostic clue is the presence of an M spike on serum electrophoresis, indicating a monoclonal gammopathy. Immunofixation Electrophoresis (IFE) separates immunoglobulin heavy and light chains:

 

  • G = IgG
  • A = IgA
  • M = IgM
  • K = Kappa light chain
  • L = Lambda light chain

 

The elevated IgM and the overproduction of kappa light chains suggest a diagnosis of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, commonly referred to as Waldenström's macroglobulinemia, which falls under the broader category of plasma cell cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe systemic infection: Infections usually cause polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia, where multiple types of antibodies are elevated rather than a single monoclonal spike. The presence of monoclonality rules out this option.

 

Option B. MGUS (Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance): MGUS can present with a monoclonal spike, but it does not typically cause systemic symptoms or organ dysfunction such as renal impairment. The patient’s symptoms suggest a more severe plasma cell disorder.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma with elevated IgG: Multiple myeloma with elevated IgG is the most common type of immunoglobulin elevated in multiple myeloma, the immunofixation pattern indicates IgM, not IgG, ruling out this choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An M spike on serum electrophoresis along with specific symptoms and immunofixation identifying elevated IgM indicates a diagnosis of multiple myeloma or a related plasma cell cancer, such as lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (Waldenström's macroglobulinemia).

choices.text: Atrophy of the right lower limb
Loss of proprioception in the left leg
Ankle clonus in the right foot

questions.text: A 40-year-old man had a RTA and was admitted to a hospital. After a few days, he had an exaggerated right-sided extensor plantar reflex and knee jerk. What other finding would be seen? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ankle clonus in the right foot

 

The presentation suggests Brown-Sequard syndrome, which is a hemisection of the spinal cord. In this condition, there's:

 

  • Ipsilateral (same side) findings:
    • Loss of proprioception and fine touch due to damage to the posterior column.
    • Upper motor neuron signs (e.g., spasticity, exaggerated reflexes, ankle clonus) due to damage to the corticospinal tract.
  • Contralateral (opposite side) findings:
    • Loss of pain and temperature sensation due to damage to the spinothalamic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrophy of the right lower limb: Atrophy is a feature of lower motor neuron lesions, not upper motor neuron lesions seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome.

 

Option B. Loss of proprioception in the left leg: Loss of proprioception would be on the same side (right leg) as the lesion in Brown-Sequard syndrome.

 

Option D. Fasciculations in the right foot: Fasciculations are also a sign of lower motor neuron lesions and are not expected in Brown-Sequard syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown-Sequard syndrome presents with ipsilateral loss of proprioception and upper motor neuron signs, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of weakness and generalized fatigue. The peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic RBCs. Her serum iron is decreased and has increased RDW. Her MCV and MCH were also low, and TIBC was high. What would her serum transferrin saturation be? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduced

 

The clinical presentation and lab findings are consistent with iron deficiency anemia. In iron deficiency anemia:

 

  • Serum iron levels are low as the body lacks sufficient iron.
  • TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity) is high as the body tries to compensate by increasing its capacity to bind iron.
  • Transferrin saturation is the percentage of transferrin (an iron-transport protein) that is saturated with iron. It is calculated as (Serum Iron / TIBC) x 100.
  • Since serum iron is low and TIBC is high, the transferrin saturation will be reduced. Typically, in iron deficiency anemia, transferrin saturation is less than 20%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In iron deficiency anemia, transferrin saturation is reduced (typically less than 20%) due to low serum iron and high TIBC.

questions.text: An infant of 3 months presents with recurrent severe infections, including pneumonia, chronic diarrhea, and oral candidiasis. He has an absence of thymic shadow on chest X-ray. Laboratory tests reveal very low levels of adenosine deaminase (ADA). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

 

The clinical presentation of recurrent severe infections, absence of thymic shadow, and low levels of adenosine deaminase (ADA) are indicative of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

 

SCID is characterized by a profound deficiency in both T and B cell function, leading to a high susceptibility to infections. ADA deficiency is one of the causes of SCID, resulting in the accumulation of toxic metabolites that damage immune cells.

 

The absence of a thymic shadow on X-ray indicates a lack of T cell development, a hallmark of SCID.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-linked agammaglobulinemia: This condition is due to a defect in the B cell tyrosine kinase gene, leading to an absence of B cells but not T cells. It primarily affects boys and presents with recurrent bacterial infections but not the absence of a thymic shadow or ADA deficiency.

 

Option B. Hyper-IgE syndrome: Also known as Job's syndrome, this condition is associated with elevated IgE levels, recurrent infections, and abnormal dentition. It does not involve the absence of the thymic shadow or low ADA levels.

 

Option D. Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID): CVID involves B cell maturation defects, leading to reduced antibody production. It does not present with ADA deficiency or thymic shadow absence. Both males and females are equally affected, and the condition is usually diagnosed later in childhood or adulthood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCID is characterized by recurrent severe infections, absence of thymic shadow, and very low levels of adenosine deaminase, highlighting defects in both T and B cell function.

questions.text: An athlete collapsed suddenly and dies. He had an abnormal septal thickening. His sibling also expired due to a cardiac condition earlier. His cardiac biopsy image is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

 

The clinical history and biopsy findings point towards hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). This condition is characterized by abnormal thickening of the heart's septum, often leading to asymmetrical hypertrophy that obstructs blood flow.

 

The cardiac biopsy image shows a characteristic "helter-skelter" or disorganized arrangement of cardiac muscle fibers, a hallmark of HCM.

 

The sudden death in an athlete and a family history of similar cardiac events strongly support this diagnosis, as HCM is often associated with sudden cardiac death during exertion due to outflow obstruction and arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: This condition involves normal-sized ventricles with rigid, stiff heart walls, leading to impaired diastolic filling. It does not present with significant septal hypertrophy, or a disorganized fiber arrangement seen in HCM.

 

Option C. Dilated cardiomyopathy: In this condition, the heart chambers are dilated and the heart muscle is weakened, leading to systolic dysfunction. It does not involve septal thickening or the characteristic histological findings of HCM.

 

Option D. Cardiac tumor/myocarditis: These conditions would present differently, often with symptoms related to inflammation or mass effect rather than sudden death associated with septal hypertrophy and disordered muscle fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by asymmetrical septal hypertrophy, disorganized cardiac muscle fibers, and is commonly associated with sudden death in young athletes, particularly during exertion.

questions.text: In the below question mechanical receptors are given with their functions. Choose the correctly matched pair.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle - Fast Vibration

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized nerve endings located deep within the skin and other tissues. They are highly sensitive to high-frequency vibrations, making them particularly adept at detecting fast vibrations. These receptors are crucial for perceiving textures and fine details through vibration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ruffini - Fine touch: This is incorrect because Ruffini endings are mechanoreceptors that detect skin stretch, not fine touch. They are deeper in the skin and contribute to the sensation of skin deformation, which is associated with stretch rather than fine touch.

 

Option C. Meissner - Stretch: This is incorrect because Meissner's corpuscles are responsible for detecting light touch, not stretch. They are located near the surface of the skin and are sensitive to changes in texture and slow vibrations.

 

Option D. Merkel - Slow vibration: This is incorrect because Merkel cells are associated with fine touch and two-point discrimination, not slow vibrations. They are particularly sensitive to edges, points, and textures, which aids in tasks like reading Braille.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting fast vibrations, and Ruffini endings detect skin stretch.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient with the image of chromosome 15 represented here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prader-Willi syndrome

 

The image represents chromosome 15, showing a deletion specifically on the paternal chromosome. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by the deletion of a segment on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13.

 

This genetic disorder is characterized by hypotonia, poor feeding in infancy, hyperphagia leading to obesity in childhood, intellectual disability, and distinct physical features.

 

Prader-Willi syndrome can also occur due to maternal uniparental disomy (Maternal UPD), where two copies of the maternal chromosome are present, and no paternal copy is active.

 

These two mechanisms—paternal deletion and maternal uniparental disomy—are the main causes of Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

In rare cases, an issue with imprinting itself can also lead to the syndrome, but the primary focus is on the two causes mentioned.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Angelman syndrome: Angelman syndrome is caused by a deletion or inactivation of the maternal copy of chromosome 15q11-q13 or by paternal uniparental disomy. It presents with severe intellectual disability, ataxia, seizures, and a characteristic happy demeanor with frequent smiling and laughter, which differs from Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Option C. VHL syndrome: Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is a genetic disorder associated with mutations on chromosome 3, leading to various tumors, including hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas. It is unrelated to chromosome 15 deletions.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18) is a chromosomal disorder caused by an extra chromosome 18, presenting with severe intellectual disability, heart defects, and characteristic physical anomalies. It does not involve deletions on chromosome 15.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13 or by maternal uniparental disomy, and is characterized by obesity due to hyperphagia, intellectual disability, and specific behavioral traits.

choices.text: Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.
Apoferritin is the storage form.
Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood.
Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption.

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect about iron transport? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.

 

Iron metabolism involves complex processes where iron must be in the correct oxidation state to be absorbed and utilized effectively by the body. Iron in the diet is primarily found in the ferric (Fe3+) form, but for it to be absorbed across the apical membrane of enterocytes in the intestine, it needs to be converted into the ferrous (Fe2+) form. This conversion is crucial because only ferrous iron can be effectively transported into the cells. The statement in option A is incorrect because it suggests the opposite process—conversion from ferrous to ferric—before absorption, which is not accurate. The conversion actually goes from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) before iron is absorbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apoferritin is the storage form: This statement is correct. Apoferritin binds with iron to form ferritin, which is the storage form of iron within cells.

 

Option C. Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood: This is also correct. After iron is absorbed into the bloodstream, it binds to the protein transferrin, which transports it to various tissues, including the bone marrow for hemoglobin production.

 

Option D. Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption: This statement is true. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) reduces ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), which enhances its absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron must be converted from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) form for effective absorption through the apical membrane of enterocytes

questions.text: Oxygen sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors are for which of the following ion? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) K+

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors are specialized sensory receptors located in the carotid and aortic bodies that detect changes in blood oxygen levels. These receptors play a critical role in the respiratory control by responding to hypoxia (low oxygen levels). The oxygen-sensitive channels in these receptors are specifically sensitive to potassium ions (K+). When oxygen levels drop, these potassium channels close, which leads to a series of events: membrane depolarization, calcium influx, and ultimately, the release of neurotransmitters like ATP. This process triggers signals that increase respiratory activity to raise blood oxygen levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Na+: Sodium channels are important in many physiological processes, but they are not specifically sensitive to oxygen levels in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option C. HCO3-: Bicarbonate ions are involved in acid-base balance and CO2 transport but are not directly involved in the oxygen sensing mechanism of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. Cl-: Chloride ions play roles in various cellular processes, including maintaining osmotic balance, but they are not the primary ions involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary ion involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors is potassium (K+). The closure of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels during hypoxia is a crucial step in the signaling pathway that regulates respiratory response to low oxygen levels.

questions.text: How muscle spindle able to detect the length while muscle is contracting? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nuclear bag fibers

 

Muscle spindles are sensory receptors within the muscle that detect changes in muscle length and the rate of change in length. They consist of intrafusal fibers, which include both nuclear bag fibers and nuclear chain fibers.

 

These fibers are dynamic and are sensitive to the rate of change in muscle length (velocity of stretch). They play a crucial role in detecting muscle length changes during muscle contraction by responding to the speed at which the muscle length is changing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nuclear chain fibers: These fibers are more static and respond to the absolute length of the muscle rather than the rate of change. They are not primarily responsible for detecting changes during contraction.

 

Option C. Golgi tendon organ: This sensory receptor is located at the junction of the muscle and tendon. It monitors tension rather than length changes in the muscle. It is more involved in preventing muscle damage due to excessive force.

 

Option D. Other muscle receptor: This option is too vague. The specific receptor responsible for detecting the rate of change in muscle length during contraction is the nuclear bag fiber.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nuclear bag fibers in the muscle spindle are responsible for detecting the rate of change in muscle length during muscle contraction, making them essential for proprioception and motor control.

questions.text: Which of the following is earliest to rise in myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ischemia modified albumin

 

Explanation:

 

In the event of a myocardial infarction, certain biomarkers are released into the bloodstream as a result of cardiac muscle injury.

 

Among the three early markers of myocardial injury, three are particularly significant: myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA). Of these three, ischemia modified albumin is the earliest to rise and also the earliest to fall in response to myocardial ischemia. This rapid change makes it a valuable early diagnostic marker for detecting myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Troponin: Troponins are highly specific markers for myocardial injury and are considered the gold standard for diagnosing myocardial infarction. However, they do not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. Typically, troponin levels start to rise 4-6 hours after the onset of myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is an enzyme found in almost all body tissues and is not specific to cardiac tissue. It is a later marker of myocardial infarction, usually rising within 24-48 hours after the onset of symptoms.

 

Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB): CK-MB is a specific isoenzyme found in heart muscle and is used as a marker for myocardial infarction. However, it does not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. CK-MB levels typically start to increase 3-6 hours after myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ischemia modified albumin is the earliest biomarker to rise in the event of a myocardial infarction, making it a crucial early indicator for diagnosis.

questions.text: An elderly patient underwent investigations which revealed Hb 9 g/dL, TLC 50,000/mm³, ↑PT, ↑aPTT, low platelet count, and increased D-dimers. Which of the following is the likely gene affected in the patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PML- RARA


The patient's presentation with anemia, elevated white blood cell count, prolonged PT and aPTT, low platelet count, and increased D-dimers is indicative of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

 

DIC is commonly associated with Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL), previously known as AML M3. APL is characterized by a translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17, resulting in the PML-RARA fusion gene.

 

This fusion disrupts the normal function of the retinoic acid receptor, blocking the differentiation of promyelocytes and leading to an accumulation of immature cells. APL is strongly associated with DIC due to the procoagulant activity of the promyelocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BCR-ABL: BCR-ABL is a fusion gene associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), resulting from the Philadelphia chromosome translocation (t(9;22)). It leads to unregulated tyrosine kinase activity, promoting proliferation of myeloid cells. It is not typically associated with DIC.

 

Option B. NPM: Nucleophosmin (NPM) mutations are associated with a subset of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) without recurrent cytogenetic abnormalities, often presenting with a normal karyotype. It does not typically present with the coagulation abnormalities seen in DIC.

 

Option D. Inv 16: Inv(16) is associated with a specific subtype of AML (AML M4Eo), which involves abnormal eosinophils and monocytic cells. While it is an important genetic alteration in AML, it is not specifically linked with the coagulation issues seen in APL and DIC.

 

Educational Objective:


APL (acute promyelocytic leukemia) is characterized by the PML-RARA fusion gene and is highly associated with DIC, which can be identified by a combination of bleeding tendencies and abnormal coagulation profiles.

questions.text: A patient with a history of TB presents with hemoptysis. X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergilloma

 

The patient has a history of tuberculosis and now presents with hemoptysis. The chest X-ray shows a cavity with a mass inside it, which is suggestive of an aspergilloma, also known as a fungal ball.

 

Aspergilloma typically forms in pre-existing lung cavities caused by conditions such as tuberculosis. The fungal ball is composed of Aspergillus organisms and debris, and it often presents as a crescent-shaped shadow known as Monod's sign, although this may not always be clearly visible.

 

Most patients with aspergilloma are asymptomatic, but when symptoms do occur, hemoptysis is the most common presenting symptom, ranging from mild to life-threatening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchogenic cancer: While bronchogenic cancer, particularly squamous cell carcinoma, can present with cavitating lesions, it is less likely in this case given the patient's history of TB and the appearance of the cavity with a mass, which is more typical of aspergilloma.

 

Option C. Lung abscess: Lung abscesses also present as cavitating lesions, but they typically show air-fluid levels on imaging, which are not evident in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Bronchogenic cyst: Bronchogenic cysts have a completely different radiographic appearance and clinical presentation. They are typically congenital and do not present as cavitating lesions with a mass inside them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergilloma is a fungal infection that commonly occurs in pre-existing lung cavities from conditions such as tuberculosis. It presents as a cavity with a fungal ball inside and can cause hemoptysis, which may be severe.

questions.text: Sour taste is mediated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TRPV1 Channel

 

Fig: Signal transduction in taste receptors: Salt and sour tastes are mediated via the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC). This receptor has two subunits (a and g), each crossing the membrane twice, resulting in intracellular N and C termini (NT, CT). Salt is sensed following Na+ movement; sour is mediated by movement of H+. Sweet, bitter, and umami tastes are sensed via G-protein-coupled receptors that span the membrane seven times and have varying lengths of CT and NT (represented as ribbon structures). Sweet tastes are detected by the T1R2 and T1R3 families, bitter and umami tastes are detected by the T2R family and mGluR4, respectively.

 

Fig: Receptors on nociceptive unmyelinated nerve terminals in the skin. Nociceptive stimuli (eg, heat) can activate some receptors directly due to transduction of the stimulus energy by receptors (eg, transient receptor potential (TRP) channel TRPV1) or indirectly by activation of TRP channels on keratinocytes (eg, TRPV3). Nociceptors (eg, mechanoreceptors) can also be activated by the release of intermediate molecules (eg, ATP), ASIC, acid-sensitive ion channel; P2X, ionotropic purinoceptor, P2Y, G-protein-coupled purinergic receptor.

 

Sour taste is primarily mediated by the detection of H+ ions, which are present in acidic substances like citric acid. These H+ ions activate ion channels rather than G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). Specifically, the TRPV1 (Transient Receptor Potential Vanilloid Receptor Type 1) channel and acid-sensitive ion channels are involved in mediating the sour taste. These channels open in response to the presence of H+ ions, allowing the ions to enter the taste cells, which leads to the perception of a sour taste.

 

Metabotropic receptors, which involve GPCRs, mediate other taste modalities like sweet, bitter, and umami but are not involved in sour taste. The GPCR T1R1 and T1R3 are specifically involved in the sweet and umami taste pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabotropic Receptor: This type of receptor is associated with GPCRs and mediates taste sensations like sweet, bitter, and umami. It is not involved in sour taste, which is mediated by ion channels.

 

Option C. GPCR T1R1: This receptor is part of the GPCR family and is involved in detecting umami (savory) tastes, not sour tastes.

 

Option D. GPCR T1R3: This receptor is also a part of the GPCR family and contributes to the detection of sweet and umami tastes, not sour tastes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sour taste is mediated by the activation of ion channels, particularly the TRPV1 channel and acid-sensitive ion channels, in response to H+ ions from acidic substances

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, when given with erythromycin, can cause QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Astemizole

 

Astemizole is an antihistamine known to cause QT prolongation and an increased risk of Torsades de pointes, especially when combined with other medications that affect cardiac conduction, such as erythromycin. This dangerous interaction occurs because both drugs can interfere with cardiac potassium channels, prolonging the QT interval and predisposing the patient to potentially fatal arrhythmias.

 

Astemizole and terfenadine are notable among antihistamines for their high risk of causing Torsades de pointes, which has led to the withdrawal of terfenadine from the market. Astemizole, though less commonly used, still poses a significant risk when combined with drugs like erythromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cetirizine: Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine that does not significantly affect the QT interval and is not associated with Torsades de pointes when combined with erythromycin.

 

Option C. Loratadine: Loratadine is another second-generation antihistamine with a good safety profile concerning cardiac conduction and QT interval prolongation, making it a safer choice in patients requiring antihistamine treatment.

 

Option D. Promethazine: Although promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine, it does not carry the same risk of QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes as astemizole when used with erythromycin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Astemizole, when combined with erythromycin, can cause QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes due to its significant effect on cardiac potassium channels, posing a high risk of life-threatening arrhythmias.

choices.text: Increased membrane potential of the oocyte
Decreased membrane potential of the oocyte

questions.text: What mechanism occurs within the zona pellucida of an oocyte to prevent the entry of multiple sperm cells after the initial fertilization?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cortical reaction

 

The cortical reaction is critical to prevent polyspermy, which is the fertilization of an oocyte by more than one sperm. This reaction happens after the first sperm has successfully fertilized the oocyte. Enzymes from cortical granules in the oocyte are released into the space between the oocyte plasma membrane and the zona pellucida. These enzymes then modify the zona pellucida by breaking down ZP3 receptors, making it impermeable to additional sperm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acrosomal reaction: The acrosomal reaction is the process by which the sperm's acrosome releases digestive enzymes to penetrate the zona pellucida and reach the oocyte. While necessary for the initial penetration, it does not prevent subsequent sperm from entering.

 

Option B. Increased membrane potential of the oocyte and D. Decreased membrane potential of the oocyte: Changes in the membrane potential of the oocyte, whether an increase or decrease, occur as a response to sperm contact and help in triggering the cortical reaction but are not the primary mechanism for preventing polyspermy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cortical reaction is essential, as it is the primary defense against polyspermy, ensuring that only one sperm fertilizes the oocyte, thereby maintaining the correct genetic composition of the embryo.

questions.text: A patient from a military background presented with rash, fever, and altered sensorium. There is also a deficiency of the membrane attacking complex. The likely cause can be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitidis

 

Neisseria meningitidis is a bacterium that commonly causes meningococcal infections, which can lead to serious conditions such as meningococcemia and meningitis. Patients with a deficiency in the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system, specifically components C5 to C9, are at an increased risk of Neisserial infections. The MAC plays a crucial role in defending against Neisseria species by forming pores in the bacterial cell membrane, leading to cell lysis. Without this complex, individuals are susceptible to recurrent or disseminated Neisserial infections, which manifest with symptoms like rash, fever, and altered sensorium, as seen in this patient. The clinical presentation of rash, fever, and altered sensorium strongly suggests meningococcemia, a severe form of infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause a variety of symptoms, primarily in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not typically present with rash, fever, and altered sensorium linked to MAC deficiency.

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: This bacterium is associated with pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and other infections, particularly in hospital settings. It does not have a direct correlation with MAC deficiency and does not typically present with disseminated infections characterized by rash, fever, and altered sensorium.

 

Option D. Hemophilus influenzae: While Hemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections and meningitis, it is not specifically associated with MAC deficiency and does not fit the profile of disseminated Neisserial infections seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with deficiencies in the membrane attack complex (C5-C9) of the complement system are particularly susceptible to infections caused by Neisseria species, such as Neisseria meningitidis, which can lead to severe conditions like meningococcemia.

questions.text: A person was taking an antihypertensive drug and continued taking it despite developing constipation, dry mouth, and dizziness. He was taking it regularly but forgot to take it during a trip abroad and has now developed a hypertensive emergency. Which antihypertensive was he likely taking? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clonidine

 

Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in the management of hypertension. One of the common side effects of Clonidine includes dry mouth, constipation, and dizziness, which matches the symptoms described in this case. Additionally, a significant risk associated with Clonidine is the potential for rebound hypertension if the medication is suddenly discontinued, as can happen if a dose is missed. This rebound effect occurs because the body's sympathetic nervous system experiences a sudden surge in activity once the inhibitory effects of Clonidine are removed, leading to a hypertensive emergency, as seen in this patient.

 

Remember – Clonidine is safe in Pregnancy 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used for hypertension but does not typically cause rebound hypertension. Its side effects more commonly include peripheral edema rather than the symptoms described here.

 

Option C. Lisinopril: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor that does not cause the described side effects of dry mouth, dizziness, and constipation. Additionally, sudden discontinuation of Lisinopril does not lead to a hypertensive emergency.

 

Option D. Telmisartan: Telmisartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB). It generally does not cause dry mouth, constipation, or dizziness, and discontinuation does not lead to rebound hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clonidine is an antihypertensive medication that can cause dry mouth, constipation, and dizziness, and sudden discontinuation can lead to rebound hypertension, making it crucial for patients to maintain consistent dosing.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a lump in her right breast that she discovered during a self-examination. She reports that the lump is painless and has been present for about three months. A mammogram shows a suspicious mass. The biopsy shows the following image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Dystrophic calcification

questions.text: The phlebotomist needs to collect samples from a patient for various tests. Among the options provided, which sequence of blood collection for testing ensures that the sample remains uncontaminated, considering the additives present in the collection tubes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey

 

  • Light blue (Citrate tube): Collected first to avoid contamination with clot activators or EDTA that can affect coagulation studies.
  • Red (Plain tube, no anticoagulant): Collected next for serology/chemistry, avoids interference from EDTA or fluoride.
  • Lavender (EDTA tube): Collected later for hematology; prevents EDTA carryover from affecting earlier tests.
  • Grey (Fluoride oxalate tube): Collected last for glucose/lactate estimation, since fluoride inhibits glycolysis and would interfere with other tests if drawn earlier.

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2 at 28 weeks is brought to the emergency after being found unconscious at home by her mother. She is disoriented on arrival and her BP is 180/110 mmHg and 4 + proteinuria. On arrival at the emergency, she has a tonic-clonic seizure which resolves with MgSO4 administration. Once the patient is stabilized, she undergoes caesarean delivery for fetal distress. Post-partum, the below MRI is done. What is the most likely finding on imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome

 

  • The case is classic for eclampsia: pregnant woman with hypertension, proteinuria, seizures.
  • The MRI shows bilateral symmetrical areas of hyperintensity in the posterior cerebral hemispheres (parieto-occipital regions), most characteristic of PRES.
  • PRES is associated with eclampsia and presents with headache, altered mental status, seizures, and visual disturbances. MRI usually shows vasogenic edema—seen as high signal in posterior regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdural hematoma, Option B. Parenchymal hemorrhage, Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Would show focal or diffuse hyperintensity in different locations, not typically as bilateral posterior edema.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for recurrent vomiting that began 5 hours ago. He describes the vomitus as bloody and containing black specks. He drinks 10-12 beers daily and has not seen a physician in 15 years. He appears pale. Physical examination shows decreased radial pulses, delayed capillary refill, multiple spider angiomata, and a distended abdomen. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. Which of the following is most likely decreased in this patient in response to his hematemesis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Carotid baroreceptor firing activity

questions.text: A young athlete was diagnosed to have HOCM and has a harsh ejection systolic murmur. Which of the following maneuvers would most likely increase the intensity of the murmur? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valsalva maneuver

 

The intensity of the murmur in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is directly related to the degree of left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. The Valsalva maneuver decreases preload (the amount of blood returning to the heart), which in turn, increases the LVOT obstruction and intensifies the murmur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isometric Hand grip: This maneuver increases afterload (the resistance the heart pumps against), which decreases LVOT obstruction and reduces the intensity of the murmur.

 

Option C. Squatting: Squatting increases preload, leading to a decrease in LVOT obstruction and a reduction in the murmur's intensity.

 

Option D. Leaning forward: This maneuver has no significant effect on the hemodynamics of HOCM and thus does not alter the murmur's intensity. It can, however, accentuate the murmur in aortic stenosis by bringing the aortic valve closer to the chest wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HOCM, maneuvers that decrease preload (like the Valsalva maneuver) will increase the intensity of the murmur, while those that increase preload or afterload will decrease it.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. Physical examination shows nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. The spleen is palpated 5 cm below the costal margin. Her leukocyte count is 12,000/mm 3 and platelet count is 217,000/mm 3. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Smudge cells

 

  • The patient has painless lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, mild leukocytosis, and normal platelets, a presentation suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
  • Peripheral blood smear in CLL characteristically shows smudge cells, which are fragile, broken leukocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ringed sideroblasts: Seen in sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option B. Teardrop cells: Associated with myelofibrosis and marrow infiltration.

 

Option D. Rouleaux formation: Seen in multiple myeloma, characterized by stacked red blood cells.

choices.text: Increased direct to total bilirubin ratio

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of yellowing of his eyes. He has also noticed a decrease in his exercise capacity and gets quickly exhausted after minor physical activity. Examination shows scleral icterus and pale mucous membranes. He has splenomegaly. His hemoglobin concentration is 7.9 mg/dL, leukocyte count 8500/mm³ and platelet count is 1.8 lakhs/mm3. Direct antiglobulin and heterophile antibody tests are positive. Which of the following additional laboratory findings are most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased haptoglobin levels

 

  • The patient has scleral icterus, anemia, splenomegaly, and positive direct antiglobulin (Coombs) and heterophile antibody tests. This indicates autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) triggered by infectious mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus).
  • In hemolytic anemia, haptoglobin binds free hemoglobin released from destroyed red blood cells, leading to decreased serum haptoglobin levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased reticulocyte count: Reticulocyte count would be increased, not decreased, due to compensatory bone marrow response.

 

Option C. Decreased mean corpuscular volume: Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is typically normal or slightly increased in hemolytic anemia.

 

Option D. Increased direct to total bilirubin ratio: Direct to total bilirubin ratio is usually decreased because hemolysis increases indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin.

questions.text: Which ion is most responsible for the resting membrane potential (RMP): (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) K+

 

The resting membrane potential (RMP) of a cell is primarily determined by the distribution of ions across the cell membrane and the relative permeability of the membrane to those ions. Potassium ions (K+) play the most significant role in establishing the RMP. This is because the cell membrane is more permeable to K+ ions compared to other ions, and there is a higher concentration of K+ inside the cell than outside.

 

The movement of K+ out of the cell down its concentration gradient leads to a negative charge inside the cell relative to the outside. This difference in charge across the membrane is what we refer to as the RMP. Other ions, such as sodium (Na+), calcium (Ca2+), and chloride (Cl-), have some influence, but their impact is much less compared to K+.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ca2+: Calcium ions have a much smaller role in setting the RMP. They are more involved in processes like muscle contraction and neurotransmitter release rather than in establishing the RMP.

 

Option C. Na+: Sodium ions have a minimal direct role in determining the RMP under normal conditions because the cell membrane is much less permeable to Na+ at rest compared to K+. The Na+/K+ pump helps maintain the gradient of Na+ and K+, but Na+ itself does not significantly influence the RMP.

 

Option D. Cl-: Chloride ions can influence the RMP, but their effect is secondary to that of K+. Since the membrane is more permeable to K+, the RMP is predominantly a result of K+ distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by the concentration gradient of potassium ions (K+) across the cell membrane and the membrane's permeability to K+.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presented with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, night fever and chills, calf tenderness, cervical lymphadenopathy, hypokalemia, and joint pain. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

Leptospirosis is the Ans.  because the patient's presentation of symptoms, particularly conjunctival suffusion (redness of the conjunctiva), is more characteristic of Leptospirosis than the other conditions listed. This condition is caused by the Leptospira bacteria, which can lead to symptoms like retro-orbital pain, night fevers, chills, calf tenderness, and hypokalemia, all seen in this patient.

 

The key differentiator in this case is conjunctival suffusion, which is commonly observed in Leptospirosis and is not a typical feature of Dengue or other listed conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria: Malaria usually presents with high fevers, chills, sweats, and headache but does not typically cause conjunctival suffusion or calf tenderness. Additionally, hypokalemia is not a common feature of Malaria.

 

Option C. Filariasis: Filariasis is characterized by lymphatic dysfunction and can cause lymphedema or elephantiasis, but it does not present with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, or the other acute symptoms described in the patient.

 

Option D. Dengue: Dengue can present with similar symptoms such as retro-orbital pain, fever, and joint pain, making it a close differential. However, conjunctival suffusion is not a characteristic feature of Dengue, which helps to distinguish it from Leptospirosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conjunctival suffusion is a distinguishing symptom of Leptospirosis and is not commonly seen in Dengue or other similar infectious conditions.

choices.text: All boys and girl children equally affected
50% boys affected and no girl children unaffected
No boy affected and 50% children are carriers
25% boy affected and 25% girl children are carrier

questions.text: A boy born to a normal father and mother had Hemophilia. Detailed history taking revealed that the mother's side had a family history of similar affected individuals. The children born to this boy are likely to have which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No boy affected and 50% children are carriers

 

Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder, where affected males inherit the defective gene from their carrier mothers. In this scenario, the boy with hemophilia cannot pass the X-linked defective gene to his sons (as they inherit his Y chromosome). Therefore, no male children will be affected.

 

However, all daughters will inherit his X chromosome, meaning that 50% of his children (only daughters and not boys) shall be carriers of the hemophilia gene but will not exhibit the disease because they inherit a normal X chromosome from their mother.

 

Outcome:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All boys and girl children equally affected: This is incorrect because, due to the X-linked recessive nature of hemophilia, the affected father does not pass the defective X chromosome to his sons.

 

Option B. 50% boys affected and no girl children unaffected: This statement is incorrect as affected fathers cannot transmit the X-linked gene to their sons; only daughters can inherit the X chromosome.

 

Option D. 25% boy affected and 25% girl children are carrier: This does not match the inheritance pattern of X-linked recessive disorders, as male offspring will never inherit the disease from their father, and all daughters will have a 50% chance of being carriers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In X-linked recessive disorders like hemophilia, affected males do not transmit the condition to their sons, but their daughters have a 50% chance of being carriers.

 

Major X-linked Recessive Disorders (Mnemonic: "OBLIGATE"):

 

 

Other X-linked Recessive Diseases:

Skin examination shows soft tissue swelling over her proximal interphalangeal joints and subcutaneous nodules over her elbows. Serum studies show an alanine aminotransferase level of 220 U/L, aspartate aminotransferase level of 214 U/L, and creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely primary mechanism of action of the drug she is taking?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase

questions.solution: Ans. D) Ventromedial

Fall of at least 10 mmHg in diastolic BP
Occurs on head-up tilt table testing (HUTT) at an angle of at least 60˚

questions.text: All of the following are correct about definition of postural hypotension except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Within 10min of active standing

questions.text:
A patient presented to the casualty with right sided hemiparesis and aphasia for a duration of one hour. Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. rTPA will not be used if CT scan is normal

  2. Tenecteplase should not be used if BP is 160/90 mm Hg

  3. CT angiography is the initial investigation of choice

  4. rTPA contraindicated if edema is more than 1/3rd of middle cerebral artery territory
questions.solution: Ans. D) 4

questions.text: Identify the papillae of the tongue that serve a mechanical function but do not contribute to taste sensation. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Filiform

 

Filiform papillae are the most numerous papillae on the surface of the tongue. They are elongated, keratinized projections that cover the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Unlike other papillae, filiform papillae do not contain taste buds. Their primary function is to provide a rough surface that aids in the mechanical aspect of chewing by creating an abrasive texture that helps manipulate food.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Circumvallate: These papillae are located near the back of the tongue in a V-shaped arrangement just in front of the sulcus terminalis. They contain taste buds on their lateral surfaces and are responsible for the perception of bitter tastes.

 

Option C. Foliate: Foliate papillae are located on the lateral edges of the tongue. They contain taste buds that are responsible for the perception of sour tastes, although they are less prominent in humans compared to some other animals.

 

Option D. Fungiform: These mushroom-shaped papillae are scattered across the tongue's surface, particularly near the tip and sides. They contain taste buds and are responsible for the perception of sweet, salty, and umami tastes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Four types of papillae on the tongue:

  1. Filiform
  2. Fungiform
  3. Circumvallate
  4. Foliate

 

Taste buds are barrel-shaped structures located in the epithelium of the foliate and fungiform papillae, as well as on the lateral sides of the circumvallate papillae.

 

Taste buds are absent in the filiform papillae, which are the most numerous and smallest papillae on the surface of the tongue. They cover the entire dorsal surface of the tongue.

questions.text: A middle aged man came with complaints of dyspnea, chest tightness and dry cough. On imaging, he was found to have diffuse interstitial fibrosis. The biopsy of his lung was taken and is shown below. Which of the following industries he has likely been working in for the last 20 years?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Shipyard

questions.text: What among the following does not contribute to reversible dementia?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Lewy body dementia

choices.text: Collagen type III

questions.text: A CT scan of a 23 year old male is shown below. What is the likely protein involved in this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Fibrillin

questions.text: An investigator is studying cellular repair mechanisms in various tissues. One of the samples being reviewed is from the anterior horn of the spinal cord of a patient who was involved in a snowboard accident. Pathologic examination of the biopsy specimen shows dispersion of the Nissl bodies, swelling of the neuronal body, and a displacement of the nucleus to the periphery in numerous cells. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the observed findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Central chromatolysis

 

Central chromatolysis is the neuronal cell-body response to axonal injury — features include dispersion of Nissl substance, cellular swelling, and eccentric displacement of the nucleus as the neuron upregulates protein synthesis to support axonal regeneration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurodegenerative changes: Usually a chronic process with neuronal loss, Lewy bodies, neurofibrillary tangles, etc., not the acute Nissl dispersal and cell swelling seen here.


Option B. Wallerian degeneration: Refers to degeneration of the axon distal to the site of injury, not the characteristic soma changes (Nissl dispersion) described.


Option D. Reactive astrogliosis: Involves proliferation/hypertrophy of astrocytes (GFAP+) after CNS injury, not the neuronal Nissl and nuclear displacement findings.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis is brought to the physician because of dizziness, urinary incontinence, loss of vision in her right eye, and numbness and weakness of the left leg. She has had recurrent episodes of neurological symptoms despite several changes in her medication regimen. An MRI of the brain shows several new enhancing lesions in the periventricular white matter and the brainstem. Treatment with a drug that binds to CD52 is initiated. Which of the following agents was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Alemtuzumab

choices.text: Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine (750/37.5 mg) (2 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine (750/37.5 mg) (2 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy from Rajasthan weighing 50 kg is diagnosed with mixed P. vivax and P. falciparum malaria. What is the appropriate treatment regimen on day 2?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)

 

In the treatment of malaria, the choice of drugs and regimen depends on the type of malaria (whether it's P. vivax, P. falciparum, or mixed infection) and the geographic location due to different strains' drug resistance profiles. For mixed infections involving P. vivax and P. falciparum, the treatment typically includes a combination of drugs targeting both species.

 

For P. vivax malaria, chloroquine is generally used, followed by primaquine for 14 days to achieve a radical cure by eliminating hypnozoites and preventing relapse. However, in mixed infections and P. falciparum malaria, the treatment regimen includes an Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT). Specifically, in regions like Rajasthan, ACT comprises artesunate plus sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine.

 

On day 2 of treatment, sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine (which is given only on day 1) has already been administered, so the treatment continues with artesunate and primaquine.

 

Primaquine is dosed at 0.25 mg/kg for 14 days in cases of P. vivax, and the dosage calculated for this patient (weighing 50 kg) is 15 mg/day

 

(0.25 mg/kg × 50 kg = 12.5 mg, rounded to the nearest available tablet strength).

 

The correct regimen on day 2 includes Artesunate (to continue targeting the malaria parasites) and Primaquine (for radical cure and to prevent relapse), specifically at the dosage of 2.5 mg per tablet (6 tablets totaling 15 mg).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malaria Treatment Regimens:

questions.text: A 72-year-old man came with headache and blurring of vision. Kidney function tests were found to be deranged and his urine gammaglobulins were more than 3gm/dI. Electrophoresis of the urine protein is shown below. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Walderstorm macroglobulinemia

Positive interferon-gamma release assay

She has also had constipation and fatigue during the same period. Physical examination shows injected conjunctivae and tender, erythematous nodules on both shins. The lungs are clear to auscultation. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Elevated CD4+ T-cell count in bronchoalveolar lavage

choices.text: Na+ I- Symporter

questions.text: Identify the transporter of iodine from follicular cells to follicular cavity within the thyroid gland: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pendrin

 

The transport of iodine within the thyroid gland involves multiple steps, with specific transporters playing distinct roles. The sodium-iodide symporter (Na+ I- Symporter) is responsible for transporting iodine from the bloodstream into the thyroid follicular cells. However, once inside the follicular cells, iodine needs to be transported into the follicular cavity (colloid) where thyroid hormone synthesis occurs. This specific transport is carried out by the protein Pendrin, a chloride-iodide transporter. Pendrin moves iodine from the follicular cells into the colloid, facilitating the next steps of thyroid hormone production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na+ I- Symporter: This symporter is involved in the initial uptake of iodine from the bloodstream into the follicular cells, not in the transport of iodine into the colloid.

 

Option C. Calmodulin: Calmodulin is a calcium-binding messenger protein, and it does not play a direct role in the transport of iodine within the thyroid gland.

 

Option D. Claudin: Claudin proteins are involved in the formation of tight junctions in cells and do not have a role in the transport of iodine for thyroid hormone synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pendrin is the transporter responsible for moving iodine from the follicular cells into the colloid of the thyroid gland, a crucial step in thyroid hormone production.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure is 165/92 mm Hg on the left arm and 162/90 mm Hg on the right arm. He reports that he is adherent with his medication and exercise regimen. The physician adds a drug to his antihypertensive medication regimen. This drug increases serum renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels, and decreases serum aldosterone levels, without affecting bradykinin levels. Which of the following drugs was most likely added to this patient's medication regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candesartan

 

  • The drug described increases serum renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels but decreases aldosterone levels without affecting bradykinin.
  • Candesartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB). ARBs block the angiotensin II receptor, leading to decreased aldosterone production.
  • Because they block the receptor but not the production of angiotensin II, levels of renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II increase due to feedback.
  • ARBs do not inhibit bradykinin breakdown, so bradykinin levels remain unchanged.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aliskiren: Direct renin inhibitor; lowers renin and downstream angiotensins.

 

Option C. Verapamil: Calcium channel blocker; does not affect renin-angiotensin system.

 

Option D. Lisinopril: ACE inhibitor; increases bradykinin levels by blocking its degradation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely disease looking at the pattern of inheritance as provided in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

 

The pedigree in the image shows an inheritance pattern typical of X-linked recessive conditions. In this pattern, affected males inherit the disease from carrier mothers, while females are usually carriers and do not show the disease. All affected individuals are male, and carrier females are represented by circles with a dot. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome follows an X-linked recessive inheritance, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wilson’s disease: This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning both males and females are equally affected, and carriers are not seen in the pattern observed here.

 

Option C. Achondroplasia: This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. It would appear in every generation and affect both males and females equally, which is not the case in the presented pedigree.

 

Option D. Leber disease: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is inherited through maternal (mitochondrial) inheritance. It does not follow an X-linked recessive pattern and affects both sexes through maternal transmission only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-linked recessive conditions are characterized by affected males and carrier females, as males have only one X chromosome, making them susceptible if the gene is defective.

 

Major X-linked Recessive Disorders (Mnemonic: "OBLIGATE")

 

 

Other X-linked Recessive Diseases:

questions.text: An athlete who was planning for some kind of physical activity sport comes for a routine health checkup. All routine investigations turned out to be normal with non-significant ECG findings except he had a PR interval of 0.21 seconds. Which of the following is most likely? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First degree heart block

 

The PR interval on an ECG measures the time from the onset of atrial depolarization to the onset of ventricular depolarization. The normal range for the PR interval is between 0.12 to 0.20 seconds (120 to 200 milliseconds). In this case, the athlete has a PR interval of 0.21 seconds, which is slightly prolonged.

 

A PR interval greater than 0.20 seconds indicates a first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block. This is a benign condition often found in athletes due to increased vagal tone, which can slow conduction through the AV node. Although it is termed a "block," first-degree AV block is usually asymptomatic and considered a normal variant, particularly in individuals with high physical fitness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Second degree heart block: This condition involves intermittent failure of atrial impulses to reach the ventricles and is characterized by progressively lengthening PR intervals or sudden drops of QRS complexes. It is not suggested by a constant but slightly prolonged PR interval.

 

Option C. Normal ECG: Although the first-degree AV block can be a benign finding in athletes, it is still classified as an AV block due to the prolonged PR interval. Therefore, the ECG is not considered entirely normal.

 

Option D. Third degree heart block: This is a complete heart block where there is no communication between the atria and ventricles, resulting in independent atrial and ventricular rhythms. It is a severe condition and would not present with a consistent, mildly prolonged PR interval.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A PR interval greater than 0.20 seconds indicates a first-degree AV block, which can be physiological, especially in athletes with high vagal tone.

questions.text: A hospital has reported an outbreak of MRSA infection. On investigation, it was found out that a staff nurse had nasal carriage of MRSA. Which of the following drugs helps in the removal of colonization of bacteria? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Topical mupirocin

 

Topical mupirocin is the preferred agent for the elimination of nasal carriers of MRSA.

 

Decolonization therapy is the administration of antimicrobial or antiseptic agents to eradicate or suppress MRSA carriage:

 

  • Intranasal antibiotic or antiseptic (e.g., mupirocin, povidone-iodine)
  • Topical antiseptic (e.g., chlorhexidine)
  • +/- Systemic antibiotics

 

MRSA decolonization has been associated with reduction in MRSA carriage, transmission and infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral vancomycin: While effective against MRSA, oral vancomycin is not used for nasal decolonization. It is primarily used for treating severe systemic MRSA infections and Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea.

 

Option B. Inj cephalosporin: Cephalosporins are a class of antibiotics that are generally ineffective against MRSA due to resistance mechanisms. They are not used for MRSA nasal decolonization.

 

Option D. Inhaled colistin: Colistin is an antibiotic used for treating multidrug-resistant Gram-negative infections, particularly in the lungs. It is not used for nasal decolonization of MRSA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical mupirocin is the recommended treatment for the nasal decolonization of MRSA, effectively reducing the nasal carriage of the bacteria and thereby decreasing the risk of transmission and subsequent infections.

choices.text: Destruction of the central portion of the acinus

questions.text: A previously healthy 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 4 hours after the sudden onset of shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 3 years. He is 188 cm (6.2 ft) tall and weighs 70 kg; BMI is 19.8 kg/m. Physical examination shows decreased tactile fremitus, and diminished breath sounds over the left lung. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Rupture of a subpleural bleb

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) has a direct spasmolytic action on gastrointestinal (GI) smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mebeverine

 

Mebeverine is a musculotropic antispasmodic drug. It directly targets the smooth muscle of the gastrointestinal tract, causing relaxation and relieving spasms. This makes it effective in managing the abdominal pain and discomfort associated with IBS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dicyclomine: While dicyclomine can help with IBS symptoms, it works indirectly by blocking acetylcholine receptors, thus reducing muscle contractions. It's an anticholinergic drug, not a direct spasmolytic.

 

Option B. Scopolamine: Similar to dicyclomine, scopolamine is an anticholinergic drug that works indirectly to reduce smooth muscle contractions. It's not a direct spasmolytic.

 

Option D. Racecadotril: Racecadotril is an antidiarrheal medication. It works by inhibiting enkephalinase, an enzyme that breaks down enkephalins, which regulate intestinal fluid secretion. It doesn't have a direct spasmolytic action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mebeverine is a direct spasmolytic drug used in the treatment of IBS, acting directly on the GI smooth muscle to relieve spasms and pain.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to monitor PCM (paracetamol) toxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rumack Matthew

 

The Rumack-Matthew nomogram is used to assess risk of hepatotoxicity after acute paracetamol overdose based on plasma concentration vs time.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Matzke: Used for aminoglycoside dosing.

 

Option C. Hartford: Not relevant for paracetamol.

 

Option D. Naranjo: Adverse drug reaction probability scale.

choices.text: 2 FC and 1 FAB fragment
1 Variable chain and 1 constant chain
1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments

questions.text: When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end products? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments

 

When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments.

 

If an antibody molecule is digested with papain, cleavage occurs above the disulfide bonds that hold the heavy chains together. This generates 3 separate fragments, two of which are called Fab (fragment antigen binding), and one of which is called Fc (fragment crystallizable).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When an immunoglobulin molecule is digested with papain, the end products are 1 Fc fragment and 2 Fab fragments.

questions.text: A patient is presenting with a staggering gait and nystagmus (Rhomberg sign +ve) after a road traffic accident. Which lobe of cerebellum is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flocculonodular

 

The symptoms described—staggering gait, nystagmus, and a positive Rhomberg sign—are indicative of damage to the cerebellum, specifically the flocculonodular lobe. The flocculonodular lobe is responsible for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex, which is crucial for stabilizing vision during head movements. The presence of nystagmus (involuntary eye movements) suggests a disturbance in the vestibulo-ocular reflex, pointing towards a lesion in the flocculonodular lobe. This part of the cerebellum is particularly involved in coordinating the balance and equilibrium of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dentate: The dentate nucleus is involved in the planning and execution of fine motor movements rather than the maintenance of balance and posture.

 

Option C. Anterior lobe: The anterior lobe of the cerebellum is primarily associated with coordinating limb movements and maintaining muscle tone.

 

Option D. Vermis: The vermis is responsible for controlling the body's midline movements, such as the trunk and head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum is crucial for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex. Damage to this area can lead to symptoms such as a staggering gait, nystagmus, and balance issues, as seen in the case of cerebellar ataxia following trauma.

questions.text: A patient presents with hepatosplenomegaly with bone marrow having 22% plasma cells. The bone marrow biopsy had a pink acellular deposition of material as shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amyloidosis

 

The patient’s clinical presentation, including hepatosplenomegaly and an increased number of plasma cells (22%) in the bone marrow, suggests a plasma cell dyscrasia, most likely multiple myeloma.

 

 In multiple myeloma, there is overproduction of abnormal immunoglobulin light chains, particularly lambda light chains, which can be deposited as amyloid fibrils.

 

The bone marrow biopsy showing pink acellular material confirms amyloidosis, a condition where these abnormal proteins are deposited in various tissues, including the liver and spleen, leading to organ dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone marrow necrosis: This condition involves the death of bone marrow cells and would not present with acellular pink deposits seen in amyloidosis. It typically occurs due to severe conditions like leukemia or metastatic cancer.

 

Option B. T.B.: Tuberculosis affecting the bone marrow would present with granulomatous inflammation, not with a high percentage of plasma cells or acellular amyloid deposits.

 

Option C. Myxoid degeneration: This refers to a degenerative change within connective tissue, characterized by a gelatinous appearance. It does not cause acellular pink deposits and is not associated with increased plasma cells or amyloid formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloidosis can occur as a result of multiple myeloma due to the deposition of abnormal immunoglobulin light chains, which can be identified as acellular pink deposits on histology.

questions.text: Splenectomy is contraindicated in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

 

Bone marrow failure often seen in aplastic anemia, involves the failure of the bone marrow to produce sufficient blood cells. The spleen is not involved in this pathology, so splenectomy would not be beneficial. The problem lies within the bone marrow, not the spleen, making splenectomy contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenic rupture: Splenectomy is commonly indicated in cases of splenic rupture, whether due to trauma or iatrogenic causes, to prevent life-threatening hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: In cases of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), splenectomy can be an effective treatment option to achieve durable remission, although it is not the first-line treatment.

 

  • Corticosteroids and other treatments are often tried first.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia: Splenectomy may be indicated in hairy cell leukemia in cases of massive splenomegaly or persistent cytopenias to alleviate symptoms and improve blood counts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splenectomy is contraindicated in bone marrow failure, as the underlying issue resides in the bone marrow's inability to produce blood cells.
